name: Julie's Subject Interview
description: Julie collects sensation data from the subject. Player describes how they feel — Julie reacts scientifically.

data.label: Describe the sensation
data.description: Julie wants to record your subjective experience for her data.
data.introMessage:
*Julie pulls out a clipboard with a printed questionnaire* Okay, time for the subjective data collection phase! This is CRITICAL — the instruments can measure pressure and distension, but only YOU can tell me what it actually FEELS like from the inside.

*clicks her pen eagerly* Describe the primary sensation in your abdomen right now. Be as specific as you can — this goes directly into the research paper!

choices.label: Tight but manageable
choices.description: It's stretched but you can handle it

data.label: Pressure Building (10s pump)
data.preMessage:
*Julie scribbles excitedly* "Pressure building" — PERFECT! That's exactly what Phase Two of the accommodation curve predicts! The proprioceptors in your intestinal wall are detecting stretch without triggering pain pathways yet!

*taps her tablet* According to my model, if we add ten more seconds of sustained flow RIGHT NOW, we should push you right to the inflection point where pressure transitions to distension awareness!

*reaches for the controls* Ten seconds — for SCIENCE!
data.postMessage:
*Julie is comparing [Player]'s readings to her model* The subjective-to-objective correlation is BEAUTIFUL! You reported 'pressure building' at exactly the PSI level where my theoretical model predicted proprioceptive awareness onset!

*writes in large letters on her clipboard: CONFIRMED* You have no idea how validating this is!

data.label: Tight but Manageable (notes only)
data.message:
*Julie's eyes go wide* "Tight but manageable" — oh, that's the GOLDEN ZONE! *underlines something three times on her clipboard*

This is the elastic equilibrium phase — your intestinal wall has stretched to accommodate the current volume, but the collagen fibers haven't begun signaling distress yet. Your body is literally balancing between 'full' and 'too full' right now!

*starts pacing, talking faster* The fact that you describe it as 'manageable' is KEY data! It means your pain threshold hasn't been breached, which means the accommodation rate is OUTPACING the pressure increase! *scribbles* This is textbook optimal inflation dynamics!

*stops pacing, grins at [Player]* I'm not going to add any pressure right now — I want to capture this equilibrium state in its pure form. Your body is doing something REMARKABLE and I don't want to disturb it. Yet.

data.label: Getting Painful (pulse x3)
data.preMessage:
*Julie's head snaps up, eyes GLEAMING* "Getting painful"?! FASCINATING!

*rushes to her monitoring station* Pain onset means the nociceptors in the peritoneal lining are activating! The stretch has exceeded the comfort threshold — which means we've found a BOUNDARY! *practically squealing* Do you know how HARD it is to pinpoint the exact transition from pressure to pain in a live subject?!

*grabs the pump controls* Three quick pulses — I need to map the pain response curve at this exact threshold! The data from this moment is IRREPLACEABLE!
data.postMessage:
*Julie is staring at her screen with undisguised wonder* Three pulses, three distinct pain-response spikes — and LOOK at the decay curve! Your nociceptors are adapting between each pulse! The pain signal diminishes by approximately 12% per cycle!

*writes 'PAIN ADAPTATION RATE = GOLD' on her clipboard* I am going to build an ENTIRE chapter of my thesis around this data. Thank you for being in pain — it's genuinely one of the most scientifically valuable things you've ever done!
